question: Question_02_(a)
sols:
For this question, we apply the limit comparision test. Let

\begin{align*}a_{k} = \frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} - k}.\end{align*} We wish to define another
series $\sum b_{k}$ such that

\begin{align*}c = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{a_{k}}{b_{k}}\end{align*} is positive and
finite (i.e. $< \infty$). By comparing the dominant powers in the
numerator \emph{(1/3)} and denominator \emph{(2)}, we are inspired
\emph{(1/3-2 = -5/3)} to define $b_{k}$ as

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
b_{k} = k^{-5/3} = \frac1{k^{5/3}}.\end{align*} The terms $a_{k}$, $b_{k}$ are
positive for all $k \ge 2$. By the limit comparison test, if $c$ is
positive and finite, then both series converge or both diverge. We can
see that $\displaystyle \sum_{k} b_{k}$ will converge by the p-series
test, since the power on $k$ in the denominator, $5/3$, is greater than
$1$. So if $c$ is finite, then $\displaystyle \sum_{k}a_{k}$ converges.

\begin{align*}
c = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}\times k^{5/3}}{k^{2} - k} = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{k^{2}}{k^{2} - k} = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\frac{1}{1 - 1/k} = 1 < \infty.\end{align*} So $c$ is positive and finite. Therefore, by the limit
comparison test, the sum
${\color{blue}\sum_{k = 2}^{\infty}\frac{\sqrt[3]{k}}{k^{2} -k}}$
converges.
hints:
Try using the limit comparison test. You may also want to remind
yourself of the p-series test.

Consider the dominant powers in the numerator and denominator of the
terms in the series when determining a series to compare to when using
the limit comparison test.
